Description: American Electric Power agreed to cut 813,000 tons of air pollutants annually at an estimated cost of more than $4.6 billion, pay a $15 million penalty, and spend $60 million on projects to mitigate the adverse effects of its past excess emissions.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: American Electric Power, Inc. and AEP's wholly-owned subsidiary, AEP Energy Services, Inc. (AEPES) resolved an ongoing federal investigation into the submission of knowingly inaccurate reports by AEPES concerning a commodities market. AEPES agreed to pay a criminal penalty of $30 million.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

NAICS Translation: 221121: Electric Bulk Power Transmission and Control

Company: American Electric Power Company, Inc. and AEP Energy Services, Inc.
Description: American Electric Power and its subsidiary AEPES agreed to pay $30 million to resolve CFTC allegations that they repeatedly and deliberately reported false natural gas trading information, including price and volume information, to certain firms that compile natural gas price indexes. The complaint further alleged that AEP and AEPES knowingly delivered false information to price index compilers in an attempt to skew those indexes for their financial benefit.

Company: American Electric Power d/b/a Public Service Co. of Oklahoma
Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Description: On November 23, 2005, a Notice of Violation and Proposed Imposition of a Civil Penalty in the amount of $60,000, was issued for a Severity Level III problem involving the licensee's failure to provide complete and accurate information, and meet reporting requirements regarding NRC-licensed operators at the D. C. Cook Nuclear Plant. Specifically, the licensee failed to: (1) provide complete and accurate information to the NRC concerning corrective actions associated with a previous Severity Level III violation (EA-04-109); (2) notify the NRC within 30 days of NRC-licensed operators experiencing a permanent disability or illness; and (3) provide complete and accurate information concerning the medical condition of individuals on new or renewal NRC reactor operator license applications.

Description: To resolve a multistate air pollution lawsuit, AEP agreed to invest approximately $4.6 billion to cut over 800,000 tons of emissions yearly from its 16 power plants. AEP also agreed to pay $75 million for penalties and environmental projects. All this was part of a settlement that also involved the U.S. Justice Department, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-american-electric-power-0

An eight-state coalition reached an $8.5 million settlement with American Electric Power under which the companyagreed to reduce air pollution emissions to downwind states from its coal-fired electric power plants. The agreement enhanced a 2007 air pollution settlement with AEP.
In a revision of a 2007 air pollution settlement with eight states, American Electric Power agreed to spend an additional $4 million on programs to improve air quality.

Description: Equipment failed to meet PUC operating requirements
FY 2005 and 2006 equipment with system-average interruption duration that exceeded allowable limit
FY 2007 system-wide System Average Interruption did not meet ERCOT standard Duration Index

For reporting year 2008, TCC reported its system-wide System Average Interruption Duration Index (SAIDI) value exceeded the standard by more than 30%, it had 30 feeders with a SAID[ value in the top 10% of the worst feeders for two or more consecutive years, 18 feeders with a System Average Interruption Frequency Index ( SAIFI) value inthe top 10% its worst feeders for two or more consecutive years, 9 feeders with a SAIDI value more than 300% greater than system average for two or more consecutive years,and one feeder with a SAIFI value more than 300% greater than the system average for two or more consecutive years.
Violations related to the reliability and continuity of service
